Article Brain Shooting Stars From Moving Cars. Skip to content Home Subscribe to Posts Books Submit Content « Older posts Tannins in sorghum and benefits focus of genetic research By Phys.org: Biotechnology News | July 12, 2012 - 10:53 pm | Biology - Biotechnology Leave a comment They might be called a blessing or a curse—tannins, which are present in certain sorghums, contain health-promoting antioxidant properties, but also provide a bitter taste and decreased protein digestibility. To better understand tannins, their role… Continue reading →
Prisoners of Belief: Exposing and Changing Beliefs That Control Your Life By admin | July 12, 2012 - 9:57 pm | Books Leave a comment Belief is ultimately the key to happiness. Your most deeply held core beliefs are the bedrock of your personality. They determine your feelings of worth, competence, belonging, lovability, security, trust, and self-reliance. Negative core beliefs can imprison you behind bars of conviction. Written by the authors of Self-Esteem, this book shows you how to become a personal scientist, test your core beliefs objectively, subtly shift your more negative convictions, and escape from the prison of belief to a freer, more satisfying life.“”A book that will help people come face-to-face with core beliefs, and examine and challenge them. This new … Continue reading →
Discussion Arcs of APA Presidents from the 1970s By Eric Schwitzgebel | July 12, 2012 - 6:37 pm | discussion arcs , sociology of philosophy Leave a comment One of the highest forms of recognition a philosopher in the U.S. can receive is the presidency of an APA division. Lists of the APA divisional presidencies thus provide information, not filtered through current lenses, of people who were regarded as… Continue reading →
The Little Psychotherapy Book: Object Relations in Practice By Shannon Fitzgerald | July 12, 2012 - 6:35 pm | Book Reviews , Boundaries , Critical Terms , Dimensional Nature , Educator , Emotional Reactions , Evolution , Frankland , General , Healthy Relationships , Incapacity , Insight , Levels Of Perception , Multidimensional Nature , Offering Solutions , Patient Experiences , Projective Identification , Psychiatric Program , Psychiatrist , Psychodynamic Psychotherapy , Psychology , Psychotherapist , psychotherapy , Real Person , Relationships With Others , Resolve , Scenarios , Theoretical Model , Treatment , Work Issues Leave a comment The Little Psychotherapy Book by Allan G. Frankland is a user-friendly, small (187 pages) manual designed to assis understanding psychodynamic psychotherapy from an object relations (O-R) perspective “in a dynamic and easy-to-follow way.” It presents very manageable chapters dedicated to different topics and issues that a therapist likely would need to consider in effectively treating a [...] Continue reading →
From aflatoxin to sake: A case of microbe domestication By Phys.org: Biotechnology News | July 12, 2012 - 5:00 pm | Biology - Biotechnology Leave a comment What do beer, dogs and cats, and corn all have in common? All of them are the end products of the process of domestication. Almost everybody knows that a number of different animals and plants have been bred for qualities that benefit humans. But few p… Continue reading →
Faster, less expensive device gives lab test results in 15 minutes at point-of-care By Phys.org: Biotechnology News | July 12, 2012 - 2:25 pm | Biology - Biotechnology Leave a comment Researchers at Sandia National Laboratories have developed a lab-on-a-disk platform that they believe will be faster, less expensive and more versatile than similar medical diagnostic tools. Continue reading →
Joblessness and Symbolic Loss By Tyler J. Andreula | July 12, 2012 - 1:37 pm | American Culture , Anger , anxiety , Bustle , Career , Catalano , Competency , Current Trends , Department Of Labor , depression , Depressive Symptoms , Different Things , Disgust , Disorders , Dooley Wilson , Dramatic Rise , Fear , General , grief , Grief and Loss , Hatred , Joblessness , Life Stress , Myriad , Peace , Phenomenon , Professional Life , Self-Esteem , Self-Help , Sixteen Years , Stress , Stressors , Symbolic Meanings , Terrorist Attack , Unemployed Persons , Unemployment Rate , United States , Work Issues , Year 2012 Leave a comment We live in a stressful society. We need to keep up with the hustle and bustle of everyday, as well as professional, life. Stress might feel more commonplace than a sense of peace. Although there are several difficult, nationwide events that we are all currently adapting to, one of the most talked-about stressors in modern [...] Continue reading →
Memories serve as tools for learning and decision-making, new study shows By Medical Xpress: Neuroscience News | July 12, 2012 - 12:22 pm | neuroscience Leave a comment (Medical Xpress)—When humans learn, their brains relate new information with past experiences to derive new knowledge, according to psychology research from The University of Texas at Austin. Continue reading →
BBC Future column: Why I am always unlucky but you are always careless By tomstafford | July 12, 2012 - 5:15 am | Reasoning Leave a comment My most recent column for the BBC Future website, the original is here From lost keys to failed interviews, we blame other people for mishaps but never ourselves, because assuming causes helps us to make sense of the world. When my wife can’t find her keys, I assume it is because she is careless. When [...] Continue reading →
The Power of Awareness By admin | July 12, 2012 - 3:56 am | Books Leave a comment Reprint of 1952 first edition. Full facsimile of the original edition, not reproduced with Optical Recognition Software. Neville Lancelot Goddard was born in Barbados in 1905. He came to the United States to study drama at the age of seventeen and whilst touring with his dance company in England he developed an interest in metaphysics after striking up a conversation with a Scotsman. The Scotsman lent him a series of books on the powers of the mind. On his return he gave up the entertainment industry to devote his full attention to the study of spiritual and mystical matters. After … Continue reading →
Oligodendroglia cells protect neurons against neurodegeneration By Medical Xpress: Neuroscience News | July 11, 2012 - 10:29 pm | neuroscience Leave a comment (Medical Xpress)—Johns Hopkins researchers say they have discovered that the central nervous system’s oligodendroglia cells, long believed to simply insulate nerves as they“fire”signals, are unexpectedly also vital to the survival of neurons. Dama… Continue reading →
White rot fungus boosts ethanol production from corn stalks, cobs and leaves By Phys.org: Biotechnology News | July 11, 2012 - 10:00 pm | Biology - Biotechnology Leave a comment Scientists are reporting new evidence that a white rot fungus shows promise in the search for a way to use waste corn stalks, cobs and leaves–rather than corn itself–to produce ethanol to extend supplies of gasoline. Their study on using… Continue reading →
Alzheimer’s plaques in PET brain scans identify future cognitive decline By Medical Xpress: Neuroscience News | July 11, 2012 - 9:00 pm | neuroscience Leave a comment Among patients with mild or no cognitive impairment, brain scans using a new radioactive dye can detect early evidence of Alzheimer’s disease that may predict future decline, according to a multi-center study led by researchers at Duke University Medic… Continue reading →
Stress management training may help reduce disease activity in multiple sclerosis By Medical Xpress: Neuroscience News | July 11, 2012 - 9:00 pm | neuroscience Leave a comment A new study shows that taking part in a stress management program may help people with multiple sclerosis (MS) prevent new disease activity. The study is published in the July 11, 2012, online issue of Neurology, the medical journal of the American Aca… Continue reading →
Alzheimer’s Disease By Anthony Risser | July 11, 2012 - 7:04 pm | Uncategorized Leave a comment In Preventing Alzheimer’s, Mutation May Aid Drug QuestThe New York TimesBy GINA KOLATA11 July 2012 [snip] Two decades ago, researchers began discovering rare gene mutations that cause Alzheimer’s disease in all who inherit them. Now, they have foun… Continue reading →
Two proteins offer a‘clearer’way to treat Huntington’s disease By Medical Xpress: Neuroscience News | July 11, 2012 - 7:00 pm | neuroscience Leave a comment In a paper published in the July 11 online issue of Science Translational Medicine, researchers at the University of California, San Diego School of Medicine have identified two key regulatory proteins critical to clearing away misfolded proteins that… Continue reading →
Kayak Morning: Reflections on Love, Grief and Small Boats By Jennifer Whitten | July 11, 2012 - 6:34 pm | Anomalous Right Coronary Artery , Book Reviews , Challen , Continuance , Daughter Amy , Dealing With Grief , Deeper Understanding , Family , Finality , Finitude , General , Grief and Loss , honesty , Kayak Paddle , Kayaking , Meditation , Motivation and Inspiration , Personal Stories , Psyche , Reflections , Right Coronary Artery , Roger Rosenblatt , Seminarian , Small Boats , Small Revelations , Spiritual Struggles , Spirituality , Straightforward Narrative , Two And A Half Years Leave a comment Roger Rosenblatt’s Kayak Morning: reflections on love, grief, and small boats mirrors the structure of grief itself: nonlinear; highlighting times of confusion, searching, yearning, aching, and love; full of small revelations that prove useful; and forming a space we dip into and out of, as the kayak paddle enters the water and rises again. Do [...] Continue reading →
Banana genome helps fruit on the slippery slope By Phys.org: Biotechnology News | July 11, 2012 - 6:30 pm | Biology - Biotechnology Leave a comment French scientists on Wednesday announced they had sequenced the DNA code of the banana, a vital crop whose future is darkened by emerging pests and complicated by its strangely inbred character. Continue reading →
Study identifies how muscles are paralyzed during sleep By Medical Xpress: Neuroscience News | July 11, 2012 - 6:05 pm | neuroscience Leave a comment Two powerful brain chemical systems work together to paralyze skeletal muscles during rapid eye movement (REM) sleep, according to new research in the July 11 issue of The Journal of Neuroscience. The finding may help scientists better understand and t… Continue reading →
Native American populations descend from three key migrations By Phys.org: Biotechnology News | July 11, 2012 - 6:01 pm | Biology - Biotechnology Leave a comment Scientists have found that Native American populations—from Canada to the southern tip of Chile—arose from at least three migrations, with the majority descended entirely from a single group of First American migrants that crossed over th… Continue reading →
Strong communication between brain and muscle requires both having the protein LRP4 By Medical Xpress: Neuroscience News | July 11, 2012 - 5:44 pm | neuroscience Leave a comment Communication between the brain and muscle must be strong for us to eat, breathe or walk. Now scientists have found that a protein known to be on the surface of muscle cells must be present in both tissues to ensure the conversation is robust. Continue reading →
Individual differences in altruism explained by brain region involved in empathy By Medical Xpress: Neuroscience News | July 11, 2012 - 5:00 pm | neuroscience Leave a comment What can explain extreme differences in altruism among individuals, from Ebenezer Scrooge to Mother Teresa? It may all come down to variation in the size and activity of a brain region involved in appreciating others’perspectives, according to a study… Continue reading →
Scientists place 500-million-year-old gene in modern organism By Phys.org: Biotechnology News | July 11, 2012 - 3:50 pm | Biology - Biotechnology Leave a comment It’s a project 500 million years in the making. Only this time, instead of playing on a movie screen in Jurassic Park, it’s happening in a lab at the Georgia Institute of Technology. Continue reading →
Just Be Happy? Striking a Balance with Positive Psychology By Lauren Suval | July 11, 2012 - 3:45 pm | Adversity , Barbara Fredrickson , Counterpart , Emotional Reaction , Frame Of Mind , General , Gloom , grief , Happiness , Insult , Mental Health and Wellness , Mentality , Negative Emotion , Negative Emotions , Negative Feelings , Optimistic Outlook , Positive Psychology , Psychologist , Psychology , Repression , Resiliency , Self-Esteem , Self-Help , Stressor , Trauma , Traumas Leave a comment In the field of positive psychology, cultivating positive emotions is encouraged, along with garnering an optimistic outlook on adversity. After all, usually it’s how we perceive circumstances that determine how we feel about a particular event. If we choose to select thoughts that spin the source of angst in a positive light, we can feel [...] Continue reading →
Researchers find tobacco protein enhances crop immune systems By Phys.org: Biotechnology News | July 11, 2012 - 2:09 pm | Biology - Biotechnology Leave a comment A study led by Associate Prof. Kenji Nakahara at Hokkaido University in Japan has found a component in tobacco that makes crop immune systems more resistant to viral attacks. Continue reading → 1 2 › »
